sub_title: Associate Professor (Tenured) at Leiden Institute of Chemistry
summary:
My scientific career focuses on the study of heterogeneously catalyzed processes on the atomic scale using surface science techniques and density functional theory. I am interested in the fundamental aspects that govern physical and chemical processes taking place at the surfaces of nano-sized materials.
I study different chemical reactions that are enabled or enhanced by the use of catalysts. Examples of these chemical reactions are H2 dissociation, CO oxidation and chlorine production. Using a combination of surface science techniques under ultrahigh vacuum conditions and in situ operando methods I follow the changes of catalytic surfaces before, during and after reaction, while at the same time measuring the reactants and products. This combination enables me to link surface morphology to catalytic reactivity.
When more fundamental insights in these processes are gained, better catalysts can be developed, thereby saving energy, resources and money.

profile_positions.description: Using operando scanning probe microscopy, I study the relationship between structure and reactivity for model catalysts in the Deacon process, the catalytic oxidation of HCl to produce chlorine. Currently, in the chemical industry Cl2 is mainly produced by electrolysis, using large amounts of electricity. This makes this very important process environment-unfriendly and expensive. Another possible production route is via the use of a catalyst. There is currently one catalyst available that can compete with Cl2 production via electrolysis. This catalyst, however, is based on ruthenium, a scarce and expensive material. My goal is to unravel the reaction mechanisms to understand the superiority of this metal. When this fundamental insight is gained, catalysts that are based on cheaper and more abundant materials can be developed. Ultimately, the production of chlorine can be realized saving energy, resources and money.
profile_positions.title: Veni postdoctoral research fellow

profile_positions.description: During my postdoctoral period at the Fritz-Haber-Institut I studied high pressure CO oxidation on nanoparticles supported on (ultra)thin oxide films grown on single crystal surfaces. The catalysts are prepared and characterized under ultra-high vacuum conditions, using scanning tunneling microscopy and infrared spectroscopy as the main tools. The production of CO2 is measured using gas chromatography. After the reaction, the catalysts are investigated ex situ, and relationships between morphology and activity are established.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Alexander von Humboldt Research Fellow

profile_positions.description: During my PhD project I investigated the dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on bare and CO-precovered flat and stepped single crystal surfaces (Ru(0001) and stepped Pt). The dissociation process was studied both experimentally, using supersonic molecular beam techniques, and theoretically, using density functional theory and quantum and quasi-classical dynamics calculations.
